file_content.text: I have nothing for you now.
You. Where's my son? I thought I told you to get my son back!
Your husband took him to Korriban.
Calm down.
The boy should be on Korriban in no time.
I took care of it.
I took the liberty of putting him on the shuttle myself.
I sent your boy to Korriban.
Oh, okay. Sorry I raised my voice. It's just, you know--a mother cares deeply about her son.
How did you manage to convince my husband?
Calm arguments and a sympathetic ear went a long way.
It just took some patience.
Unfortunately, I had to kill him.
He left me no choice.
Shame. My husband died as he lived--a coward.
He wasn't stupid. He backed down.
He knew not to fight me.
Smart. I always knew my husband was a coward.
Honestly, I think he knew what was best all along.
Your husband saw reason.
Oh? Maybe so. I... I guess married people sometimes forget how to talk to each other.
But at least my son's future is assured. Thank you very much, and here is the promised payment.
Thank you for returning my son to me. I don't know what became of my husband, and I don't much care.
Soon, Zi'am will be on a shuttle to Korriban. You did what was needed.
Of course.
You don't care that your husband's dead?
That's callous.
My husband was a coward.
Credits--now.
Here's your reward, as promised.
Zi'am may hate me for getting his father killed--but I hear hate and grief make for a fine Sith.
There's no time to waste! My husband's taken my son to the shuttle port--you can't let them get away!
Excuse me, stranger. I don't mean to be overly familiar, but I think you're just the kind of person who can help me.
My coward of a husband has taken my son, and I need someone with the wit and muscle to bring him back.
Why would your husband take your son?
He must have had a reason.
Because he's both a coward and a fool.
Your marital problems aren't my business.
I don't care.
Pah! My marriage has been dead for years. This is about my son.
To be fair, you do seem a touch... hostile.
I'm not surprised he ran.
You would act the same way in my place.
My son is gifted. Do you understand me? Gifted. In the Force. He has the ability to train on Korriban and become Sith!
But my idiotic husband has kidnapped my son. He plans to deny him his training and keep him from his rightful glory!
Why would your husband do that?
I don't understand.
He's clearly jealous.
I'll stop him.
Yes! He must!
It seems like the boy should have a say in a decision this important.
What does your son want?
Zi'am wants what any boy wants--to make his parents proud, to become a strong man and protect his mother in her old age.
My husband trained on Korriban. He had his chance at glory but failed--now he runs errands for a slimy Hutt.
I will not have my son do the same! Please, you must help me.
Fine.
Is there a reward?
I'm not wealthy, but I'd give everything I have for my son.
Now you're speaking my language.
I like the sound of that.
Tell me where to go.
You've got yourself a deal.
Agreed.
Good. I knew I'd find somebody sensible eventually.
Why not talk to him yourself?
My husband once trained to be a Sith. The fact that he didn't finish doesn't diminish his skills as a fighter.
I hope you'll reconsider. I would pay you well.
I suppose I could do it, for the money.
Since you're paying.
Oh, all right.
Good. Excellent.
He took my son to the shuttle port. A comm officer there who owed me a favor contacted me when they showed up.
Be careful. My husband may not be willing to walk away peacefully.
Go yourself. [Refuse quest]
If you really understood what it was like to be a mother, you wouldn't hesitate to help. Ah, me--a mother's lot is a lonely one.
You've earned quite the reputation around town already, and my husband refuses to cooperate with me!
I have nothing to say to you.
